sentences.text: The '''2024 European Parliament election''' was held in the European Union (EU) between 6 and 9 June 2024. It was the tenth Elections to the European Parliament|parliamentary election since the 1979 European Parliament election|first direct elections in 1979, and the first European Parliament election after Brexit. A total of 720 Member of the European Parliament|Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) were elected to represent more than 450 million people from 27 Member state of the European Union|member states.{{Efn|name=seats|In September 2023, the European Council had increased the number of MEPs from 705 to 720.}} This election also coincided with a number of #Concurrent elections|other elections in some European Union member states.

sentences.text: The European People's Party led by Ursula von der Leyen won the most seats in the European Parliament. The pro-EU Centrism|centrist, Liberalism|liberal, Social democracy|social democrat and environmentalist parties suffered losses, while anti-EU Right-wing populism|right-wing populist parties made gains. The right-wing European Conservatives and Reformists Group|European Conservatives and Reformists group overtook the centrist Renew Europe group to win the fourth most seats, while another right-wing group, Patriots for Europe, the successor of Identity and Democracy, won the third most seats. In addition, a far-right group, Europe of Sovereign Nations Group|Europe of Sovereign Nations, was formed, becoming the smallest group in the Parliament. In total, 187 MEPS (25% of Parliament) belonged to the hard-right which is more members than ever before in history.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |title=Europe’s far right won ground in the EU elections. Can they unite to wield power?|url=https://apnews.com/article/european-parliament-election-far-right-b9339cf1a7d2067bf6fa1941c166936d# |work=The AP |date=June 11, 2024|author1=Ella Joyner}}</ref>

sentences.text: The 2019 European Parliament election|2019 election saw an increase in the turnout, when 50.7% of eligible voters had cast a vote compared with 42.5% of the 2014 European Parliament election|2014 election. This was the first time that turnout had increased since the first European Parliament election in 1979 European Parliament election|1979. In 2024, the Eurobarometer data shows that 71% of Europeans say they are likely to vote in June, 10% higher than those who said they would in 2019.

sentences.text: Since the last European-wide election, the right has continued to rise across Europe, remaining however split, mainly by the Russian invasion of Ukraine and Russian relations issue. The centre-right European People's Party Group|EPP has "raised eyebrows" among some commentators for its efforts to charm parties in the European Conservatives and Reformists Group|ECR to create a broad conservative block, which could upset the long-standing status-quo that has seen the EPP share power with the centre-left Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats|S&D and the centrist Renew Europe|Renew Group.

sentences.text:
{{main|Qatar corruption scandal at the European Parliament}}
The Qatar corruption scandal at the European Parliament|Qatargate corruption scandal, which began in December 2022, had destabilized the European Parliament following the arrest of several MEPs including Marc Tarabella; Andrea Cozzolino and Eva Kaili who was stripped of her vice presidency. Other suspects in the case include Francesco Giorgi (former assistant at the European Parliament)|Francesco Giorgi, the parliamentary assistant of MEP Andrea Cozzolino, Pier Antonio Panzeri, founder of the Fight Impunity NGO; Niccolo Figa-Talamanca, head of the No Peace Without Justice NGO; and Luca Visentini, head of the International Trade Union Confederation. Following the scandal, the European Parliament revised its rules of procedure and its code of conduct in September 2023

sentences.text:
{{see also|2024 European Parliament election in Portugal#Date}}
The dates chosen for the elections conflicted with a long weekend in Portugal, where Portugal Day, a national holiday, was celebrated on 10 June, which was expected to suppress turnout. Despite an attempt by Portuguese leaders to find a compromise, no change was made to the default date of 6–9 June, which required unanimity to be changed.

sentences.text: Elections to the European Parliament are regulated by the Treaty on European Union, Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and the Act concerning the election of the members of the European Parliament by direct universal suffrage (the Electoral Act). The Electoral Act states that the electoral procedure is governed by the national provisions in each member state, subject to the provisions of the act. Elections are conducted by direct universal suffrage by proportional representation using either a Party-list system|list system or single transferable vote.<ref name="41976X1008(01)"/> The national electoral threshold may not exceed 5% of votes cast.<ref name="41976X1008(01)"/>

references.text: <ref name="41976X1008(01)">{{CELEX|id=01976X1008(01)-20020923|text=Consolidated text: Act concerning the election of the members of the European Parliament by direct universal suffrage}}</ref>

sentences.text: In June 2018, the Council of the European Union|Council agreed to change the EU electoral law and to reform old laws from the 1976 Electoral Act as amended in 2002. New provisions included a mandatory 2% threshold for countries with more than 35 seats and rules to prevent voters from voting in multiple countries. After the Act was adopted by the Council following consent given by the European Parliament in July 2018, not all member states ratified the Act prior to the 2019 elections, which took place under the old rules. As of 2023, the reform has yet to be ratified by Cyprus and Spain; Germany only ratified in summer 2023.

sentences.text: On 3 May 2022, the European Parliament voted to propose a new electoral law, which would contain provisions for electing 28 seats on transnational lists. As of 2024, this reform has not been approved by the Council, which must approve it unanimously, meaning the election will be conducted under the 1976 Electoral Act as amended in 2002.

sentences.text: As a result of Brexit, 27 seats from the British delegation were distributed to other countries in January 2020 (those elected in 2019, but not yet seated took their seats). The other 46 seats were abolished with the total number of MEPs decreasing from 751 to 705.

sentences.text: A report in the European Parliament proposed in February 2023 to modify the apportionment in the European Parliament and increase the number of MEPs from 705 to 716 in order to adapt to the development of the population and preserve degressive proportionality. It was passed in the plenary in June 2023. On 13 September 2023, the European Parliament consented to this decision, which was adopted by the European Council on 22 September 2023.

sentences.text: In the run-up to the 2014 European Parliament election|2014 European Parliament elections a new informal system was unveiled for the selection of the President of the European Commission|European Commission President (known colloquially as the Spitzenkandidat system) dictating that whichever party group gained the most seats (or the one able to secure the support of a majority coalition) would see their candidate become President of the Commission. In 2014, the candidate of the largest group, Jean-Claude Juncker, was eventually nominated and elected as Commission President. European political party|European party leaders aimed to reintroduce the system in 2019, with them selecting lead candidates and organizing a televised debate between those candidates. In the aftermath of the election List of German defence ministers|German Defense Minister Ursula von der Leyen was chosen as Commission President, even though she had not been a candidate prior to the election, while Manfred Weber, lead candidate for the EPP, which had gained the most seats, was not nominated as he was unable to secure support from any other party. Following this appointment of a Commission President who had not been a Spitzenkandidat, some called for the system to be abandoned, while others called for it to be revived in the 2024 elections.

sentences.text: The centre-right European People's Party|EPP held its congress in Bucharest on 6–7 March 2024 to elect its presidential candidate and adopt its election programme. Nominees required the backing of their own member party and not more than two other EPP member parties from EU countries, with nominations closing on February 21.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.epp.eu/news/european-peoples-party-congress-in-bucharest-press-registration |title=European People's Party Congress in Bucharest |date=2024-01-11 |website=www.epp.eu |access-date=1 February 2024 |archive-date=1 February 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240201202654/https://www.epp.eu/news/european-peoples-party-congress-in-bucharest-press-registration |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: On 19 February 2024, Ursula von der Leyen announced her intention to run, supported by the Christian Democratic Union of Germany|CDU. On 7 March von der Leyen was elected presidential candidate with 400 votes in favour, 89 against and 10 blank, out of the 737 EPP delegates at the EPP congress. Among others, it is believed that the French and Slovenian delegations voted against.

sentences.text: The centre-left Party of European Socialists|PES held its congress in Rome on 2 March. Nominees required the backing of nine PES full member parties or organisations, with nominations closing on 17 January.

sentences.text: On 18 January, the PES announced that the Luxembourgish European Commissioner for Jobs and Social Rights Nicolas Schmit was the sole nominee to meet the nominating requirements. He was then nominated on 2 March during the party congress, along with the adoption of the election programme.

content.title: Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party

sentences.text: The Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party|ALDE party held its extraordinary congress in Brussels on 20–21 March 2024. On 7 March 2024, following months of speculation, Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas announced that she had rejected the offer from ALDE to be the party's Spitzenkandidat. Luxembourg's former Prime Minister Xavier Bettel announced that he is not interested in the post either.

sentences.text: During the 2–4 February 2024 congress in Lyon, the European Green Party elected Terry Reintke and Bas Eickhout as its two presidential candidates and adopted its election programme. Nominees were Bas Eickhout, Elīna Pinto, Terry Reintke, Benedetta Scuderi.

{{Main|Potential enlargement of the European Union}}
Various sources wrote that an increased influence of right-wing and far-right parties in the European Parliament could  derail Accession of Ukraine to the European Union|Ukrainian accession, as polling showed low support for EU enlargement in countries where such parties have power. Exceptions were Poland's Law and Justice supporting Ukrainian accession, and Hungary's Fidesz – a party highly sceptical of Ukraine – being in favour of bids from Accession of Serbia to the European Union|Serbia and Accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the European Union|Bosnia and Herzegovina, two countries with governments favourable to Russia.<ref name=chatham/>

sentences.text: In January 2024, Charles Michel announced he would step down early as president of the European Council to run for the European Parliament instead. This would have meant that European Union leaders would potentially discuss his successor in the summer as, if elected to the European Parliament, he would have had to step down because of prohibition of the dual mandate. His mandate had been to set to expire in November 2024. For this unanticipated decision Michel was criticised by EU officials and diplomats. He was criticised by his political ally Sophie in 't Veld who questioned his "credibility". This timing was further criticised for potential disruptions it could cause, as Article 2(4) of the European Council's Rules of Procedure provide that, if its President leaves office early, he "shall be replaced, where necessary until the election of his or her successor, by the member of the European Council representing the Member State holding the six-monthly Presidency of the Council". This would have been the Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, whose country would be scheduled to take over the rotating presidency of the European Council on 1 July. On 26 January 2024, Michel withdrew his candidacy and thus delayed his departure.

sentences.text:
{{main|Russian interference in European politics}}
On 27 March, the Czech Republic sanctioned the news site ''Voice of Europe'', claiming that the site is part of a network for pro-Russian influence. The following day, Belgian Prime Minister Alexander De Croo|De Croo, referring to the sanctions during a debate in the Belgian parliament, said that Russia had targeted MEPs, but also paid them. On 2 April, the Czech news portal ''Denik N'' reported, citing several ministers, that there are audio recordings of the German Far-right politics|far-right politician Petr Bystron (MP, AfD) that incriminate him of having accepted money. On 12 April, it became known that the Belgian public prosecutor's office is investigating whether European politicians were paid to spread Russian propaganda. In addition to Bystron, the investigation is also targeting Dutch MEP Marcel de Graaff (FvD) and German MEP Maximilian Krah (AfD). Ukrainian politician and businessman Viktor Medvedchuk, who is close to Russian President Vladimir Putin, is believed to be the man behind Voice of Europe.

sentences.text: Ahead of the 2024 European Parliament election, National Rally spokespeople Jordan Bardella and Caroline Parmentier announced they would part ways with Alternative for Germany after the election and not include the AfD in the Identity and Democracy|ID group due to controversial statements on Nazi Germany made by AfD lead candidate Maximilian Krah in an interview and allegations of Chinese espionage influence on the party. Italy's Lega (political party)|Lega and the Czech Freedom and Direct Democracy|SPD backed the position taken by the National Rally, but Vlaams Belang declined to support expulsion of the AfD from the ID group or rule out further cooperation with the AfD, while criticising Krah's remarks. The Danish People's Party conditioned future cooperation with the AfD on Krah's exclusion from the ID group. The AfD was expelled from the group on 23 May.

sentences.text: After the European elections, there are often changes or creation of new Political groups of the European Parliament|political groups by the national parties in the European Parliament. This concerns both the new parties that have not yet announced which group they will be part of, and the parties already present in the European Parliament who choose to change group at the beginning of a new legislature.

references.text: <ref name="New Groups">{{Cite web|url=https://www.foederalist.eu/2024/05/european-election-new-groups.html|title=At the bazaar of the political groups: Which parties could look for new partners in the European Parliament after the EU election?|website=Der (europäische) Föderalist|date=2024-05-28|access-date=2 June 2024|archive-date=2 June 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240602162707/https://www.foederalist.eu/2024/05/european-election-new-groups.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name="New Groups"/> According to the Parliament's rules of procedure, a political group requires at least 23 MEPs from at least one-quarter of the Member state of the European Union|Member States (7 out of 27), and a political declaration, setting out the purpose of the group.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/RULES-9-2021-01-18-RULE-033_EN.html|title=Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament|website=European Parliament|date=2021-01-15|access-date=2 June 2024|archive-date=13 February 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240213222929/https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/RULES-9-2021-01-18-RULE-033_EN.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: Several news outlets have speculated on the possibility of a new group guided by the German Bündnis Sahra Wagenknecht party, created in January 2024. This 'left-conservative' and Euroscepticism|eurosceptic group could also include La France Insoumise, the Five Star Movement, ANO 2011, Course of Freedom, Direction – Social Democracy, Voice – Social Democracy, the Lithuanian Regions Party, For Stability!, and Together for Catalonia (2020)|Together for Catalonia.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/elections/news/germanys-rebel-wagenknecht-plots-new-left-wing-group-in-eu-parliament/|title=Germany's rebel Wagenknecht plots new left-wing group in EU Parliament|website=Euractiv|date=2024-02-22|access-date=2 June 2024|archive-date=30 May 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240530100805/https://www.euractiv.com/section/elections/news/germanys-rebel-wagenknecht-plots-new-left-wing-group-in-eu-parliament/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: After the expulsion of the AfD from ID, it is uncertain where its MEPs will be part of a group after the election. On 30 May, RTL (Hungarian TV channel)|RTL Hungary reported that Our Homeland Movement|MHM and AfD were considering forming a new group. This 'far-right' and Euroscepticism|eurosceptic group could include also Victory (Greek political party)|Niki and Republic (Slovakia)|Republic Movement.

<ref name="New Groups"/> After Revival (Bulgarian political party)|Revival was expelled from ID party, the party organized the 'Sofia Declaration' with the Republic Movement, Forum for Democracy, Our Homeland Movement, Alternative for Sweden and the Agricultural Livestock Party of Greece on 12 April 2024.<ref>{{cite news|work=BTA|url=https://www.bta.bg/en/news/bulgaria/652506-parties-from-nine-countries-sign-joint-declaration-at-vazrazhdane-organized-conf|date=12 April 2024|title=Parties from Nine Countries Sign Joint Declaration at Vazrazhdane-Organized Conference|access-date=2 June 2024|archive-date=24 May 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240524125154/https://www.bta.bg/en/news/bulgaria/652506-parties-from-nine-countries-sign-joint-declaration-at-vazrazhdane-organized-conf|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: The first debate was held on Monday, 29 April 2024 from 19:00 to 20:30 CET at the Theater aan het Vrijthof in Maastricht, Netherlands. All ten registered European political party|European Political parties were invited to the debate.<ref name="Maastricht"/>

references.text: <ref name="Maastricht"/> It was hosted by Studio Europa Maastricht and Politico Europe and was European Broadcasting Union|EBU’s Eurovision News Exchange distributed the feed to its public service media network of members.<ref name="Maastricht"/> An initiative of Maastricht University, it was the third edition of the so-called "Maastrich Debate" <ref name="Maastricht"/><ref>{{Cite web|date=2024-01-24|title=POLITICO partners with Studio Europa Maastricht to host 2024 Maastricht Debate|url=https://www.politico.eu/politico-partners-with-studio-europa-maastricht-to-host-2024-maastricht-debate/|website=Politico Europe|access-date=30 March 2024|archive-date=30 March 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240330220550/https://www.politico.eu/politico-partners-with-studio-europa-maastricht-to-host-2024-maastricht-debate/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: The debate questions focused on three main themes: climate change, foreign and security policy, and EU democracy.

references.text: <ref name="Maastricht"/> During the debate, Ursula von der Leyen indicated she would be open to a deal with the European Conservatives and Reformists Group|European Conservatives and Reformists group after the election saying that the collaboration “depends very much on how the composition of the Parliament is, and who is in what group”.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2024-04-30|title=Von der Leyen opens the door to Europe's hard right|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/von-der-leyen-hard-right-maastricht-debate-giorgia-meloni-viktor-orban-schmit/|website=Politico Europe|access-date=3 May 2024|archive-date=3 May 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240503124004/https://www.politico.eu/article/von-der-leyen-hard-right-maastricht-debate-giorgia-meloni-viktor-orban-schmit/|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: The second debate was held on Tuesday, 21 May 2024 from 17:00 to 18:15 in Brussels, Belgium.

references.text: <ref name="Bruegel"/> It was hosted by the think tank Bruegel and the Financial Times. The debate questions focused on economic policy in the EU.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2024-05-22|title=Renew, ID lead pre-EU election debate as EPP's von der Leyen keeps low profile|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/economy-jobs/news/renew-id-lead-pre-eu-election-debate-as-epps-von-der-leyen-keeps-low-profile/|website=Euractiv|access-date=22 May 2024|archive-date=23 May 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240523065238/https://www.euractiv.com/section/economy-jobs/news/renew-id-lead-pre-eu-election-debate-as-epps-von-der-leyen-keeps-low-profile/|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web|date=2024-05-22|title=The homegrown problems facing the EU's next leader|url=https://www.ft.com/content/07e6bd05-11d4-4072-8ab4-53ffe4771be0|website=Financial Times|access-date=22 May 2024|archive-date=22 May 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240522190034/https://www.ft.com/content/07e6bd05-11d4-4072-8ab4-53ffe4771be0|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: The third debate was held on Thursday, 23 May 2024 from 15:00 to 17:00 CET at the European Parliament in Brussels, Belgium. It was hosted by the European Broadcasting Union together with the European Parliament and it was broadcast on public service media channels and online platforms members.<ref name="EBUdebate"/> The debate took place in English, with interpretation into all 24 official EU languages and International Sign Language. It was the third edition of the so-called "Eurovision Debate".

references.text: <ref name="EBUdebate">{{Cite web |url=https://www.ebu.ch/news/2024/05/eurovision-debate |title=Eurovision Debate: Lead candidates meet for definitive showdown on 23 May |website=EBU |date=2024-05-02 |access-date=3 May 2024 |archive-date=3 May 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240503143040/https://www.ebu.ch/news/2024/05/eurovision-debate |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20240415IPR20392/2024-elections-media-arrangements-for-eurovision-debate-and-election-night |title=2024 European elections: Media arrangements for Eurovision Debate and Election Night |website=European Parliament |date=2024-04-29 |access-date=30 April 2024 |archive-date=30 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240430063014/https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20240415IPR20392/2024-elections-media-arrangements-for-eurovision-debate-and-election-night |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Invitations to the debate were sent by the EBU to the ten recognised European political party|European Political parties, with only one lead candidate allowed to be nominated from each of the seven Political groups of the European Parliament.

references.text: <ref name="EBUdebate"/> On 7 May, EBU announced the candidates for the debate. Two parties, the ECR and ID, were considered by EBU not eligible to take part in the debate, since they have not nominated lead candidates for the Presidency of the European Commission and.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Eurovision Debate 2024 line-up announced |url=https://www.ebu.ch/news/2024/05/eurovision-debate-2024-line-up-announced |date=2024-05-07 |website=EBU |access-date=16 May 2024 |archive-date=10 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240610054606/https://www.ebu.ch/news/2024/05/eurovision-debate-2024-line-up-announced |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Far right cries censorship after exclusion from EU election debate |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/far-right-cries-censorship-after-exclusion-ebu-from-eu-election-debate/ |date=2024-05-13 |website=Politico Europe |access-date=16 May 2024 |archive-date=16 May 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240516190359/https://www.politico.eu/article/far-right-cries-censorship-after-exclusion-ebu-from-eu-election-debate/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The debate questions focused on six main topics: Economy and Jobs, Defence and Security, Climate and Environment, Democracy and Leadership, Migration and Borders, Innovation and Technology.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |title=Eurovision Debate: Further details announced |url=https://www.ebu.ch/news/2024/05/eurovision-debate-further-details-announced |date=2024-05-16 |website=EBU |access-date=22 May 2024 |archive-date=22 May 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240522190019/https://www.ebu.ch/news/2024/05/eurovision-debate-further-details-announced |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: *''EUROMAT'' allows users to compare their positions on 20 statements with the answers given by the European political party|European political parties. The result is presented as a percentage of agreement with each party. At the end, users can see the stances of each group. The EUROMAT was created as a joint project of the NGOs Pulse of Europe and Polis 180 and the blog ''Der (europäische) Föderalist'' and is available in eight languages.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web|title=EUROMAT for the 2024 European elections|url=https://euromat.info/en|access-date=2024-06-07|language=en|website=EUROMAT|archive-date=7 June 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240607064402/https://euromat.info/en|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web|title=Election aid: Euromat soon online|url=https://table.media/en/europe/news/election-aid-when-the-euromat-goes-online/|website=TABLE EUROPE|date=2024-05-23|access-date=7 June 2024|archive-date=7 June 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240607163029/https://table.media/en/europe/news/election-aid-when-the-euromat-goes-online/|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web|title=The EUROMAT for the 2024 European election|url=https://www.foederalist.eu/2024/05/euromat-2024-election.html|website=Der (europäische) Föderalist|date=2024-05-23|access-date=7 June 2024|archive-date=2 June 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240602162712/https://www.foederalist.eu/2024/05/euromat-2024-election.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: *''VoteMatch.eu'' is a comprehensive collection of VAAs, with a unique application tailored for each member state. This application first matches users with political parties within their own country. While answering the questions, users can see the stances of the national parties (but not all, it depends on the country), and, in some countries, their arguments. This is because votematch.eu aggregate VVA proposed by external actors at the national level. After this initial matching and because each VAA share at least 15 questions, users can compare their results with those in other member states. The overall platform was developed by German Federal Agency for Civic Education|bpb and Dutch ProDemos.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |title=What party in the EU is your best match? |url=https://votematch.eu/ |access-date=2024-06-06 |language=en |website=votematcheurope |archive-date=2 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240602192140/https://www.votematch.eu/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: *''VoteTracker.eu'' allows users to visualise the votes of the outgoing MEPs on 18 selected votes, and to find the MEPs who best match their convictions. The website allows MEP to submit explanations of their stances.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |title=VoteTracker.eu |url=https://votetracker.eu/ |access-date=2024-03-23 |website=votetracker.eu |archive-date=17 March 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240317094625/https://votetracker.eu/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: *''EuroMPmatch'' is a collaborative project between EUmatrix and the European University Institute aimed at enhancing citizen engagement in EU policy-making. By analyzing MEPs' actual voting records on 20 key topics, the project offers citizens a quiz to determine alignment with MEPs, parties, and political xgroups. It has been translated in 25 languages.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web | url=https://eumatrix.eu/en/blog/EUmatrix-partners-with-European-University-Institute-to-launch-EuroMPmatch | title=EuroMPmatch: EUmatrix partners with European University Institute to launch a new project | access-date=2 May 2024 | archive-date=2 May 2024 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240502080531/https://eumatrix.eu/en/blog/EUmatrix-partners-with-European-University-Institute-to-launch-EuroMPmatch | url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: *''EU&I'', developed by the European University Institute in Florence, offers 30 questions to which the user can answer from ‘completely agree’ to ‘completely disagree’. They can then give more weight to certain questions. The result is presented as a percentage of agreement with each national party. The site has been translated into 20 languages. They had more than 150 000 users.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |title=Euandi2024 |url=https://euandi.eu/ |access-date=2024-06-04 |website=Euandi2024 |language=en |archive-date=4 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240604181106/https://euandi.eu/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=New EU&I platform launched to help voters navigate European Parliament Elections {{!}} UCD Research |url=https://www.ucd.ie/research/news/2024/neweuiplatformlaunchedtohelpvotersnavigateeuropeanparliamentelections/body,752366,en.html |access-date=2024-06-04 |website=www.ucd.ie |archive-date=20 May 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240520095913/https://www.ucd.ie/research/news/2024/neweuiplatformlaunchedtohelpvotersnavigateeuropeanparliamentelections/body,752366,en.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: *''Adeno'' is an application that allows users to discover the European group that best matches their convictions through 100 questions (20 in the express mode) covering 10 themes. The application also offers a multiplayer mode. It is available on Android and iPhone.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |title=Adeno - Apps on Google Play |url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.francoismari.adeno&hl=en_US |access-date=2024-03-23 |website=play.google.com |language=en-US |archive-date=23 March 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240323190012/https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.francoismari.adeno&hl=en_US |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-03-09 |title=Adeno |url=https://apps.apple.com/fr/app/adeno/id6476220832 |access-date=2024-03-23 |website=App Store |language=fr-FR |archive-date=17 March 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240317094631/https://apps.apple.com/fr/app/adeno/id6476220832 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text:
*''Palumba'' is an application, developed by an association of young professionals, offers 27 questions to be answered ‘for’, ‘against’ or ‘neutral’. Explanations are provided for each question. The application provides the result in the form of a percentage of agreement for each European group and displays the closest national parties. The application is available on Android and iPhone and is available in over 30 languages (including regional dialects)
*The Bloom association, whose goal is to fight the destruction of the ocean, the climate, and livelihoods, ranked the European groups both globally and at the national scale on 4 issues: ocean, climate, biodiversity and environmental justice. The page is available in 5 languages.

sentences.text: About 357 million people were eligible to vote in 27 countries. Of those, around 182 million people voted. This represents 51.05 % of the total eligible voters, the highest percentage of voter turnout since 1994.

Elected MEPs from the Netherlands' Farmer–Citizen Movement (BBB) and New Social Contract (NSC), Czech Republic's Mayors and Independents (STAN), Denmark's Liberal Alliance (Denmark)|Liberal Alliance (LA) and Germany's Family Party of Germany|Family Party also submitted requests to join the EPP Group.

As a result, the ECR became the third-largest faction in the European Parliament, overtaking Renew Europe in the process.

sentences.text: In June 2024, it was reported that five elected MEPs from Volt Europa, two of whom from the Volt Netherlands|Netherlands and three from Volt Germany|Germany, had begun negotiations both with Renew Europe and the Greens–European Free Alliance|Greens/EFA to join their respective ranks on a stable basis. On June 20, the Volt MEPs released a joint press statement recommending to join Greens/EFA, which they perceived as closer to their stance against right-wing populism, while expressing concerns over the presence of parties such as Czech Republic's ANO 2011 and the Netherlands' People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD) – which had agreed to join a coalition with the right-wing populist Party for Freedom (PVV) to form the Schoof cabinet – in the ranks of Renew.

sentences.text: On 3 July 2024, the co-spokesperson of The Left in the European Parliament – GUE/NGL|The Left, Manon Aubry, announced that Italy's Five Star Movement (M5S), who were previously part of Non-Inscrits and failed to create a new group with Germany's Bündnis Sahra Wagenknecht|BSW after the election, had submitted an official request to join the group, who had already admitted the MEPs from Italian Left following the election. Despite initial concerns, mainly related to the M5S's past alliances with the UK Independence Party in the Eighth European Parliament, and Lega (political party)|Lega during the First Conte government, In the process, the M5S became the second most-represented party within the GUE/NGL group, behind only France's La France Insoumise.<ref name="II Movimento" /><ref name=":9" />

sentences.text:
{{Main article|Patriots for Europe}}
On 30 June 2024, the Prime Minister of Hungary and leader of the Fidesz party, Viktor Orbán, publicly announced his intention to form a new parliamentary group, named Patriots for Europe, together with Austria's Freedom Party of Austria (FPÖ) and Czech Republic's ANO 2011; the alliance needed support from parties from at least four other EU countries in order to be recognized as an official group in the European Parliament.<ref name=":6" /> As a result, the FPÖ would complete a switch from the Identity and Democracy group;<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" /> on the other hand, ANO 2011 had left Renew Europe a week before the announcement, while MEPs from Fidesz were part of Non-Inscrits since 2021, when the party had left the European People's Party.<ref name=":6" />

references.text: <ref name=":6">{{Cite web |date=30 June 2024 |title=Hungary's Orban Moves To Form New EU Parliament Group |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/hungary-s-orban-moves-to-form-new-eu-parliament-group-ef12908f |access-date=30 June 2024 |website=Barron's}}</ref>

<ref name=":7">{{Cite web |date=30 June 2024 |title=Il partito del primo ministro ungherese Viktor Orbán creerà un nuovo gruppo europeo con i partiti di estrema destra di Austria e Repubblica Ceca: si chiamerà Patrioti per l'Europa |url=https://www.ilpost.it/2024/06/30/orban-babis-fpo-nuovo-gruppo/ |access-date=30 June 2024 |website=Il Post |language=it-IT}}</ref>

<ref name=":8">{{Cite web |date=1 July 2024 |title=Il nuovo gruppo europeo di destra sovranista, che piace anche a Matteo Salvini |url=https://www.ilpost.it/2024/07/01/viktor-orban-nuovo-gruppo-europeo-destra-salvini/ |access-date=1 July 2024 |website=Il Post |language=it}}</ref>

sentences.text: Portugal's Chega officially entered the alliance on 2 July, while Italy's Lega also publicly expressed interest in joining the new group. On 5 July, Spain's Vox announced their intention to enter Patriots for Europe, after leaving the ECR group, The following day, both Denmark's Danish People's Party (DF) and Belgium's Vlaams Belang switched from ID to the new group; as a result, Patriots for Europe met the EU Parliament's minimum threshold for formal recognition.<ref name=":15" /> An MEP from the DF party, Anders Vistisen, stated that they agreed to join the alliance upon the condition that each national member would be allowed to pursue their own foreign policy, including on matters such as the Russian invasion of Ukraine.<ref name=":16" />

references.text: <ref name=":13">{{Cite web |last=Hernández-Morales |first=Aitor |date=1 July 2024 |title=Portugal's Chega party to join Orbán's new far-right alliance |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/portugal-chega-party-andre-ventura-join-viktor-orban-new-far-right-alliance/ |access-date=1 July 2024 |website=POLITICO}}</ref>

<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":15">{{Cite news |date=7 July 2024 |title=Viktor Orbán's rightwing group hits quota for recognition by EU parliament |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jul/07/viktor-orbans-rightwing-group-hits-quota-for-recognition-by-eu-parliament |access-date=8 July 2024 |work=The Guardian |issn=0261-3077}}</ref>

<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":11" /> with Netherlands' Party for Freedom, previously in the ID group, following suit.<ref name=":112">{{Cite web |last=Bakker |first=Alexander |date=5 July 2024 |title=PVV sluit zich aan bij Patriots for Europe van Orbán |url=https://www.telegraaf.nl/nieuws/159764990/pvv-sluit-zich-aan-bij-patriots-for-europe-van-orban |access-date=8 July 2024 |website=De Telegraaf |language=nl-NL}}</ref>

<ref name=":16">{{Cite web |last=Thomsen |first=Per Bang |date=6 July 2024 |title=Dansk Folkeparti slutter sig til Orbán og hans nye allierede i Europa-Parlamentet |url=https://www.dr.dk/nyheder/udland/eu/dansk-folkeparti-slutter-sig-til-orban-og-hans-nye-allierede-i-europa-parlamentet |access-date=8 July 2024 |website=DR (broadcaster)|DR |language=da-DK}}</ref>

<ref name=":15" /><ref>{{Cite web |date=8 July 2024 |title=Vlaams Belang to join new far-right 'Patriots for Europe' group |url=https://www.brusselstimes.com/belgium/1129966/vlaams-belang-to-join-new-far-right-patriots-for-europe-eu-parliamentary-group |access-date=8 July 2024 |website=The Brussels Times}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 7 July, the President of France's National Rally (RN), Jordan Bardella, confirmed the party's intention to switch from ID to Patriots for Europe; as a result, the RN became the biggest delegation within the alliance, having elected 30 MEPs. Bardella was appointed as the president of Patriots for Europe, while Vistisen was nominated as their Chief Whip|chief whip.<ref name=":19" />

references.text: <ref name=":17" /><ref>{{Cite news |date=8 July 2024 |title=Le RN va rejoindre une nouvelle alliance au Parlement européen dirigée par le premier ministre hongrois, Viktor Orban |url=https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/live/2024/07/08/en-direct-legislatives-2024-emmanuel-macron-demande-a-gabriel-attal-de-rester-premier-ministre-pour-le-moment_6247441_823448.html?#id-1672292 |access-date=8 July 2024 |work=Le Monde |language=fr-FR}}</ref>

<ref name=":17" /> The following day, the group was officially established in the European Parliament: aside of the aforementioned parties, Italy's Lega, Czech Republic's Přísaha, Greece's Voice of Reason (political party)|Voice of Reason and Latvia's Latvia First also joined Patriots of Europe, bringing the group to a total amount of 84 MEPs, and making it the third-largest formation in the hemicycle.<ref name=":18" /><ref name=":19">{{Cite web |date=8 July 2024 |title=Patrioti europei è il terzo gruppo in Ue: Bardella (Rn) presidente e Vannacci (Lega) tra i vice |url=https://www.editorialedomani.it/politica/europa/la-lega-aderisce-ai-patrioti-europei-il-gruppo-supera-80-europarlamentari-efj85oqe |access-date=8 July 2024 |website=Domani (newspaper)|Domani |language=it-it}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 10 July, It was reported that the MEPs from a branch of Poland's Confederation Liberty and Independence|Confederation, National Movement (Poland)|National Movement, had expressed an interest in joining the PfE group, which was neither confirmed nor denied by Patriots. If the party were to join, it would confirm a split within Confederation's other factions in the EU, New Hope (Poland)|New Hope and Confederation of the Polish Crown.

references.text: <ref name="BS"></ref>

sentences.text: In June 2024, it was reported that Germany's Alternative for Germany (AfD) party, which had been expelled from Identity and Democracy before the election, was holding talks with other far-right parties for the creation of a new parliamentary group, tentatively named "The Sovereignists". According to reports, the group could also include Poland's Confederation, Bulgaria's Revival (Bulgarian political party)|Revival, Spain's Se Acabó La Fiesta (SALF), Romania's S.O.S. Romania, Slovakia's Republic Movement (Republika), France's Reconquête, Hungary's Our Homeland Movement, Greece's Niki (Greek political party)|Niki and Czech Republic's Freedom and Direct Democracy (SPD).

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last1=Lehmann |first1=Timo |last2=Müller |first2=Ann-Katrin |date=22 June 2024 |title=AfD startet im EU-Parlament Fraktionsgründung von »Die Souveränisten« |url=https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/afd-startet-im-eu-parlament-fraktionsgruendung-von-die-souveraenisten-a-70d63677-4af4-4694-82d4-298b7ed0644a |access-date=30 June 2024 |work=Der Spiegel |language=de-DE |issn=2195-1349}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |last=Baccini |first=Federico |date=24 June 2024 |title=The far right in the EU Parliament pushes for a new group |url=https://www.eunews.it/en/2024/06/24/the-far-right-in-the-eu-parliament-in-turmoil-afd-tries-to-lead-a-new-group-with-those-excluded/ |access-date=29 June 2024 |website=eunews}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 10 July, it was reported that a new parliamentary group, named Europe of Sovereign Nations Group|Europe of Sovereign Nations (ESN), had officially formed, having met the minimum requirements to get formal recognition within the European Parliament. The group was officially launched later the same day; MEPs from Germany's AfD (the largest party in the group), Poland's Confederation, Bulgaria's Revival, France's Reconquête (excluding the former members who had left the party to join the European Conservatives and Reformists Group|ECR), Czech Republic's SPD, Hungary's Our Homeland Movement, Slovakia's Republika and Lithuania's People and Justice Union, all joined ESN, bringing the group to a total amount of 25 MEPs.<ref name="EV" /> René Aust (AfD) and Stanisław Tyszka (NN) were elected co-chairpersons of the parliamentary group.<ref name="EN" />

references.text: <ref name="EN">{{cite web |last1=Liberero |first1=Jorge |last2=Genovese |first2=Vincenzo |date=10 July 2024 |title=AfD and allies form new far-right group in Brussels called Europe of Sovereign Nations |url=https://www.euronews.com/my-europe/2024/07/10/afd-and-allies-form-new-far-right-group-in-brussels-called-europe-of-sovereign-nations |accessdate=10 July 2024 |website=Euronews}}</ref>

sentences.text: Three MEPs, Maximilian Krah (from Germany's AfD), Braun and Milan Mazurek (from Slovakia's Republika) were all reportedly excluded from joining the group, due to the Antisemitism|anti-semitic and Holocaust denial|Holocaust-denying nature of their previous public statements. The co-leader of AfD, Alice Weidel, commented and said that "no anti-semites should have a place in a potential group with [her] party." Despite previous speculations, Romania's S.O.S. Romania was also excluded from ESN, due to some of the involved delegations expressing concerns about the party's declared goal to "redesign Eastern Europe's map" to establish the so-called "Greater Romania", a hypothetical Nation state|Nation-state roughly resembling the Kingdom of Romania in the interwar period.

references.text: <ref name="EV">{{cite web |last=Neubert |first=Kjeld |date=10 July 2024 |title=German AfD launches third far-right group 'Europe of Sovereign Nations' |url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/politics/news/german-afd-launches-third-far-right-group-europe-of-sovereign-nations/ |accessdate=10 July 2024 |website=Euractiv}}</ref>

sentences.text: To be elected Commission President, a candidate must be proposed by the European Council with a Voting in the Council of the European Union|reinforced qualified majority (at least 72% of the states representing at least 65% of the population) and receive a majority of the votes of the members of the European Parliament (at least 361 out of 720).

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/european-council/role-nominations-appointment/|title=The role of the European Council in nominations and appointments|website=European Counil|access-date=4 July 2024}}</ref>
<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/council-eu/voting-system/qualified-majority/|title=Qualified majority|website=European Counil|access-date=4 July 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 27 June, during the European Council meeting, national leaders proposed Ursula von der Leyen (EPP) as candidate for President of the European Commission, considered Kaja Kallas (ALDE) to be the appropriate candidate for High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy and elected António Costa (PES) as President of the European Council.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/meetings/european-council/2024/06/27/|title=European Council, 27 June 2024|website=European Council|access-date=2024-06-28}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 18 July 2024, Ursula von der Leyen was re-elected president of the European Commission in a secret ballot, with 401 votes in favour, 284 against, and 22 cast blank or invalid votes.

|website=European Parliament|date=2024-07-18|access-date=2024-07-18}}</ref>
